inference:
If $x \le 3$, then $f(x) = 9-2x$.
Then $f(f(x)) = f(9-2x)$.
If $9-2x \le 3$, then $9-2x \le 3 \implies 6 \le 2x \implies 3 \le x$.
In this case, $f(9-2x) = 9 - 2(9-2x) = 9-18+4x = 4x-9$.
We need $f(f(x)) = x$. Thus, $4x-9 = x$, which gives $3x = 9$, or $x=3$.
But this is only possible if $x \le 3$, and we require $x=3$.
So $f(f(x)) = x$ for $x=3$ if $f(f(3)) = 3$, which is $f(9-2(3)) = f(3) = 9-2(3) = 3$.

If $x > 3$, then $f(x) = ax+b$.
$f(f(x)) = f(ax+b)$.
If $ax+b \le 3$, $f(ax+b) = 9 - 2(ax+b) = 9-2ax-2b$.
We need $9-2ax-2b = x$.
$9-2b = 0$ and $-2a = 1$, so $a=-\frac{1}{2}$.
$9-2b = 0 \implies 2b=9$, $b = \frac{9}{2}$.
Thus $f(x) = -\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{9}{2}$ for $x>3$.
$f(3) = 3$. $3 = ax+b = a(3)+b \implies 3 = 3a+b$.
Then $3a+b = 3$. $3(-\frac{1}{2}) + b = 3$.
$-\frac{3}{2} + b = 3$, so $b = \frac{9}{2}$.
Thus $f(x) = \begin{cases} 9-2x, & x \le 3 \\ -\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{9}{2}, & x > 3 \end{cases}$
We must have $f(f(x))=x$ for $x>3$.
$f(f(x)) = f(ax+b) = 9-2(ax+b) = 9-2ax-2b$.
Then $9-2ax-2b = x \implies -2a=1$, so $a=-\frac{1}{2}$.
$9-2b = 0 \implies b = \frac{9}{2}$.
Then $f(x) = \begin{cases} 9-2x, & x \le 3 \\ -\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{9}{2}, & x > 3 \end{cases}$.
$a + b = -\frac{1}{2} + \frac{9}{2} = \frac{8}{2} = 4$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{4}$
ground_truth:
Setting $x = 0,$ we get $f(0) = 9.$ Since $9 > 3,$ $f(9) = 9a + b.$ Hence, $$f(f(0)) = f(9) = 9a + b.$$But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $9a + b = 0.$

Setting $x = 1,$ we get $f(1) = 7.$ Since $7 > 3,$ $f(7) = 7a + b.$ Hence, $$f(f(1)) = f(7) = 7a + b.$$But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $7a + b = 1.$

Subtracting the equations $9a + b = 0$ and $7a + b = 1,$ we get $2a = -1,$ so $a = -1/2.$ From $9a + b = 0,$ we get $b = -9a = 9/2.$ Hence, $$a + b = -1/2 + (9/2) = \boxed{4}.$$

question:
If $x \le 3$, then $f(x) = 9-2x$.
Then $f(f(x)) = f(9-2x)$.
If $9-2x \le 3$, then $9-2x \le 3 \implies 6 \le 2x \implies 3 \le x$.
In this case, $f(9-2x) = 9 - 2(9-2x) = 9-18+4x = 4x-9$.
We need $f(f(x)) = x$. Thus, $4x-9 = x$, which gives $3x = 9$, or $x=3$.
But this is only possible if $x \le 3$, and we require $x=3$.
So $f(f(x)) = x$ for $x=3$ if $f(f(3)) = 3$, which is $f(9-2(3)) = f(3) = 9-2(3) = 3$.

If $x > 3$, then $f(x) = ax+b$.
$f(f(x)) = f(ax+b)$.
If $ax+b \le 3$, $f(ax+b) = 9 - 2(ax+b) = 9-2ax-2b$.
We need $9-2ax-2b = x$.
$9-2b = 0$ and $-2a = 1$, so $a=-\frac{1}{2}$.
$9-2b = 0 \implies 2b=9$, $b = \frac{9}{2}$.
Thus $f(x) = -\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{9}{2}$ for $x>3$.
$f(3) = 3$. $3 = ax+b = a(3)+b \implies 3 = 3a+b$.
Then $3a+b = 3$. $3(-\frac{1}{2}) + b = 3$.
$-\frac{3}{2} + b = 3$, so $b = \frac{9}{2}$.
Thus $f(x) = \begin{cases} 9-2x, & x \le 3 \\ -\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{9}{2}, & x > 3 \end{cases}$
We must have $f(f(x))=x$ for $x>3$.
$f(f(x)) = f(ax+b) = 9-2(ax+b) = 9-2ax-2b$.
Then $9-2ax-2b = x \implies -2a=1$, so $a=-\frac{1}{2}$.
$9-2b = 0 \implies b = \frac{9}{2}$.
Then $f(x) = \begin{cases} 9-2x, & x \le 3 \\ -\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{9}{2}, & x > 3 \end{cases}$.
$a + b = -\frac{1}{2} + \frac{9}{2} = \frac{8}{2} = 4$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{4}$

inference:
Let $f(x)$ be a function defined as follows:
If $x \le 3$, then $f(x) = 9-2x$.
If $x > 3$, then $f(x) = ax + b$.
We want $f(f(x))=x$ for all $x$.

For $x \le 3$, we have $f(x) = 9-2x \le 3$. Then $6 \le 2x$, so $3 \le x$. Since $x \le 3$, we must have $x = 3$.

If $x > 3$, then $f(x) = ax+b$. If $ax+b \le 3$, then $f(f(x)) = f(ax+b) = 9-2(ax+b) = 9-2ax-2b = x$.
This implies $-2a = 1$, so $a = -\frac{1}{2}$, and $9-2b = 0$, so $b = \frac{9}{2}$.
Then $f(x) = -\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{9}{2}$ for $x > 3$.
We need $f(3) = 9-2(3) = 3$.
Also, $f(3) = -\frac{1}{2}(3)+\frac{9}{2} = \frac{6}{2} = 3$.
So $f(x) = \begin{cases} 9-2x, & x \le 3 \\ -\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{9}{2}, & x > 3 \end{cases}$
Then $a+b = -\frac{1}{2}+\frac{9}{2} = \frac{8}{2} = 4$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{4}$
ground_truth:
Setting $x = 0,$ we get $f(0) = 9.$ Since $9 > 3,$ $f(9) = 9a + b.$ Hence, $$f(f(0)) = f(9) = 9a + b.$$But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $9a + b = 0.$

Setting $x = 1,$ we get $f(1) = 7.$ Since $7 > 3,$ $f(7) = 7a + b.$ Hence, $$f(f(1)) = f(7) = 7a + b.$$But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $7a + b = 1.$

Subtracting the equations $9a + b = 0$ and $7a + b = 1,$ we get $2a = -1,$ so $a = -1/2.$ From $9a + b = 0,$ we get $b = -9a = 9/2.$ Hence, $$a + b = -1/2 + (9/2) = \boxed{4}.$$
